metadata.sermon_title: Season After Pentecost (Trinity Sunday & Second Sunday after Pentecost)
metadata.sermon_start_end: Imagine for a moment that you are the parent of a child, or young person, who appears to be on the verge of self-destruction. [...] and he shall redeem Israel from all his iniquities. (130:7–8)

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon treats two distinct passages as separate reflections rather than a single unified movement. While it identifies the uniqueness of the Trinitarian formula in 2 Corinthians, it tends toward generalities about 'love' and 'sin' rather than mining what is exclusive to these specific texts.
quotes: The one that we read today is the longest, richest, and fullest of all his valedictory blessings.
The depth of which the psalmist is actually speaking here is the depth of the knowledge that he and everyone else is a 'miserable offender.'
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Identify the specific 'nowhere else' quality of the text. For Psalm 130, focus more sharply on the paradoxical link between 'forgiveness' and 'fear' as a unique biblical logic.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The exegesis is thin. It relies on psychological analogies (the desperate parent) or liturgical history (the Book of Common Prayer) rather than the Hebrew/Greek context or the specific theological history of Israel/Corinth. The 'parent' analogy for Paul is a homiletical device, not historical-critical exegesis.
quotes: One commentator called it almost too painful to read.
There used to be a way of teaching all this from the Book of Common Prayer...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the actual linguistic tension of the Greek in 2 Cor 13 or the cultic/national context of the 'watchman' in Psalm 130 to ground the sermon in the 'then' before moving to the 'now'.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete in its psychological reach—mentioning drug addiction, anorexia, and the 'zeitgeist' of removing 'miserable offenders' from liturgy. However, it risks becoming a general discourse on 'human love' rather than a specific application of the Word.
quotes: Maybe he is hooked on drugs and failing in school, maybe she is anorexic and starving herself...
The removal of this line has robbed us of a powerful buttress to the biblical concept of sin...
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Avoid the 'glimmer of radiance' language which borders on natural theology. Apply the Word more sharply to the specific 'lostness' of the modern congregation's self-reliance.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a pattern of 'Illustration -> Textual Observation -> General Truth'. The hearer is invited to reflect on their own life (application) separately from the textual analysis. The 'present of revelation' is hindered by the split between the two Sunday texts.
quotes: Reflect on your own life. Think about those people who have borne with you.
The idea that we can add up our virtues... is decisively repudiated in this verse.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: The text itself must 'expound' the hearer. Instead of asking the hearer to 'think of people,' let the Trinitarian grace of the text confront the hearer's current isolation.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Strongest point. The sermon explicitly deals with 'misery' (the depths, the miserable offender) and 'redemption' (forgiveness, self-giving love). It correctly identifies that misery is 'before God' and not just a psychological state.
quotes: The depth... is the depth of the knowledge that he and everyone else is a 'miserable offender.'
God’s love spends itself to the very last drop of the blood of the Son.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'gratitude' aspect. The transition to 'joyous and liberating knowledge' is present but could be more robustly linked to the Spirit's work in the congregation.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon flirts with the 'two ways' by mentioning 'self-destruction' and 'being lost,' but it leans heavily toward a universalized 'love that persists in breaking through our resistance.' The 'eternal loss' is largely absent, replaced by 'estrangement.'
quotes: ...the purpose of an all-powerful Father to redeem his entire creation from its impulse toward self-destruction.
The God who pursues us even beyond the grave...
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the 'narrow way' more urgently. If sin is a 'primordial catastrophe,' the possibility of remaining in that catastrophe (lostness) must be a real weight in the sermon.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as the 'incarnate love' and the 'telos' of the blessing. The doctrine of the two natures is implicit in the discussion of the Trinity, but Christ often serves as an illustration of God's 'nature' rather than the specific mediator of salvation.
quotes: God’s love spends itself to the very last drop of the blood of the Son.
This is the love that has become incarnate in history through Jesus Christ...
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure Christ is not just a 'hint' of love but the objective ground of it. Move from 'human love is a glimmer' to 'Christ is the only light'.

8_depth_and_length.findings: The sermon is too short. At approximately 1400 words, it clocks in at 14 minutes. According to Dekker/Miskotte, 'depth needs breadth.' By splitting the focus between two different liturgical days/texts, it sacrifices the 'breadth' required for a single deep exposition.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Focus on ONE text and expand the exposition and application to at least 20 minutes (2000+ words) to allow for the 'sleeping' dogmas to actually inform the depth.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its brevity and its fragmented focus on two different texts. It relies heavily on psychological analogies and liturgical history rather than rigorous biblical exegesis. While it handles the 'misery' of the human condition with commendable sobriety, it tends toward a general theology of 'love' that lacks the sharp, specific edge of a 'new, current, proclamatory word' derived from a single pericope.
strengths: Honest treatment of human misery and the 'primordial catastrophe' of sin.
Avoids 'cheap grace' by linking forgiveness to the 'fear of the Lord'.
Clear Trinitarian framework that avoids treating God as a 'vaguely imagined Something'.
weaknesses: Insufficient length (14 minutes) prevents the necessary 'breadth' for theological depth.
Exegesis is replaced by psychological illustrations (the parent/child analogy).
The 'two ways' are softened by a focus on God's 'inexhaustible' pursuit, risking a lack of serious call to responsibility.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a meaningful religious address, but it is not yet a 'sermon' in the strict Dekkerian sense. It lacks the specific exegetical depth and the sustained focus on a single Bible passage required to recreate the Word as a current event. It is too short and too general.
